sequence.notes: Asymmetric 1,4-addition of allylsilane Grignard to cyclohexenone.

Alpha-hydroxylation of a cyclohexanone enolate using a sulfonyloxaziridine reagent (Davis oxidation). The original stereocenter is preserved, and the new hydroxyl group is formed as a mixture of diastereomers, indicated by a wavy bond.
Acetylation of a secondary alcohol. The stereochemistry of the hydroxyl/acetate-bearing carbon is unspecified (wavy bond). The reported yield is for 2 steps.
Intramolecular cyclization of an allylic silane-containing cyclohexanone derivative, likely a cascade involving the carbonyl and alkene, to form a polycyclic alcohol with an exocyclic alkene.
Methylation of a tertiary alcohol to a methyl ether using NaH and dimethyl sulfate.
Hydrolysis of an acetate ester to an alcohol, retaining the bicyclic structure, exocyclic alkene, and methoxy group.
Oxidation of secondary alcohol to ketone using Py·SO₃. The reported yield of 81% is for 3 steps, not for this single step.
Nucleophilic addition of a Grignard reagent (derived from iodocyclohexenone) to a bicyclic ketone, forming a tertiary alcohol.
Intramolecular cyclization of an unsaturated alcohol/ether to form a complex polycyclic ketone and ether (Maoecrystal V). Loss of 6 hydrogens.

An aldol-type reaction where a bridgehead ketone reacts with formaldehyde to form a hydroxymethyl group. The stereochemistry of the newly formed chiral center is indicated by a wedge bond in the screenshot.

Intramolecular cyclic acetal formation from a ketone and a primary alcohol, with methanol as an external reagent, catalyzed by trifluoroacetic acid. The original reactant SMILES was structurally invalid and replaced. Stereodescriptors were added to the product SMILES to match the chiral centers in the image. A junk fragment '[Ti]' was removed from the reagent SMILES.
Ketone reduced to a secondary alcohol. The stereochemistry of the newly formed alcohol carbon is explicitly defined as a wedge (up), with other stereocenters maintained.

An internal acetal is rearranged under acidic conditions (TsOH) to form a ketone and a primary alcohol. The methoxy group is lost from the acetal carbon, which becomes a ketone. The other part of the acetal (the internal ether oxygen) is cleaved, and a new methyl group and a primary alcohol (CH2OH) are formed through rearrangement.
Protection of primary alcohol as 2,4-dinitrobenzyl ether (OBND).

The ketone in the reactant undergoes ketal formation with methanol and cyclization with an adjacent alcohol. Simultaneously, the primary ether (CH₂OBND) is converted to a primary ester (CH₂ODNBO). The drawing of the product structure depicts the former ketone carbon with five bonds (two C-C scaffold bonds, one C-OMe bond, one C-O-DNBO bond, and one C-O-C cyclic ether bond). As this is chemically impossible, the SMILES representation omits the C-O-DNBO bond at this position to maintain valid carbon valency, while retaining the OMe and the cyclic ether bridge as represented in the initial SMILES structure provided for the product.
Nucleophilic substitution of a methoxy group with a cyanide group, retaining the complex polycyclic scaffold and the dinitrobenzoate (DNBO) moiety.
Hydrolysis of a 2,4-dinitrobenzyl ether (DNBO) to a hydroxyl group.
Nitrile and adjacent hydroxyl group convert to a lactone under acidic conditions. This is a 4-step transformation within the overall yield.

Oxidation of a polycyclic natural product with Dimethyldioxirane (DMDO) leading to epoxidation of the 5-membered ring double bond and hydroxylation of the 6-membered ring double bond (likely via epoxide opening). The hydroxyl group has unspecified stereochemistry (wavy bond).

Cyclopropane ring opening with introduction of an iodide and a new methyl group. The ketone functionality remains intact. The generated SMILES define specific stereoisomers for all centers; however, the reactant structure shows two wavy bonds and the product shows two wavy bonds (on the iodide and the new methyl group) plus a dashed methyl group, indicating either relative stereochemistry, unknown absolute stereochemistry, or a mixture of stereoisomers at these positions.

Oxidation of a secondary alkyl group (CH-CH3) to a ketone (C=O) using Dess-Martin Periodinane. Note: The starting material explicitly shows CH-CH3, which is usually not oxidized by DMP; typically, CH-OH is oxidized to C=O. The output SMILES reflect the structures as drawn, including the transformation of CH-CH3 to C=O.
Oxidation and rearrangement of an iodo-ketone to form (-)-Maoecrystal V with insertion of an ether oxygen.
